A 'covalent bond' is the chemical bond that involves the sharing of pairs of
electrons between atoms. The stable balance of attractive and repulsive forces
between atoms when they share electrons is known as covalent bonding.
For many molecules, the sharing of electrons allows each atom to attain the
equivalent of a full outer shell, corresponding to a stable electronic
configuration.

require the two atoms be of the same elements, only that they be of comparable
electronegativity. Although covalent bonding entails sharing of electrons, it is
not necessarily delocalized.
